title: Friday, 3rd August, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:05 am
BE11:05am

Hello! Welcome, hi there, good morning.

Blank canvas good morning everyone
VV75 morning
Manxish Happy Friday everyone
Soundbuy Morning all
#REF! Morning
BE11:06am

And a happy Get Angry About Amazon's Tax Day to one and all.

BE11:06am

It seems to come around faster each year.

11:06 am
BE11:07am

And as is tradition, the papers have released their festive GAAATD special supplements.

BE11:07am

Mouselet If Amazon just added a line item for the amount of income tax their employees paid ...
Mouselet (it is utterly ridiculous to think of income tax as paid by employees rather than as a cost that employers have to consider in order to employ people)
BE11:08am

The Daily Mail, there. Part of DMGT.

Mouselet (saving British high streets is also an endeavour that should be classed with saving the giant panda, or other such charismatic incompetent megafauna)
11:08 am
BE11:08am

... whose effective tax rate last year was just 12.8%, or £29m on adjusted PBT of £226m

Soundbuy It''s tough being a princess'..............bless
Ethelred Please put the Daily Hate away
BE11:09am

(Or £1.6bn revenue, if you prefer to take the odd approach of the that skyline.)

#REF! niteresting the £2bn value quoted is just a charge to hq. actual things they've sold in UK closer to 14bn. Not easy to do, but need laws on these accounting 'tricks'
Mouselet Mondi has gone up quite a bit
BE11:09am

Funny fact! DMGT's tax bill was lower than expected last year because it burned through as much of its hoard of UK tax losses as possible ahead of a law change capping their use

Ethelred Eyes passim as Hislop would say
11:09 am
BE11:09am

Which is tax dodging.

#REF! if you use the value of things sold in UK on UK P&L, PBT would be.... higher
BE11:10am

Of the perfectly legal type! To be clear!

BE11:10am

Anyway. Handy callback to Lisa Pollack's Starbucks stuff in 2012., which gives a really good overview of the joys of international organisation transfer pricing.

11:10 am
BE11:11am

https://ftalphavil...urposes-a-diagram/

Peace and Love Honesty does not rhyme with Daily Mail
BE11:11am

For our purposes, feel free on the right to suggest a better way to tax international technology companies.

BE11:12am

Didn't Nigel Lawson once propose a corporate revenue tax? That's a brutal but attractively simple solution.

Mouselet Corporate revenue tax would seem to be nearly as politically popular as individual wealth tax
Ethelred Business rates set at a minimum % of turnover for retailers
Mouselet (I think it is not unreasonable to charge on individual wealth a rate equivalent to 20% income tax on the dividend return had you put it in the FTSE100)
11:13 am
BE11:13am

Jamie, on the internal AV slack, suggested taking Amazon's average op profit margin on a three-year run rate, working it out as a % of UK revenues, and taxing that figure.

casapinos @BE sanctions from USA/EU for tax havens!!??
Provender Isn't corporate revenue tax very nearly VAT?
Manxish You could always create an overbearing piece of data protection legislation with sizeable fines for non-compliance and then use that to even thi...oh, hang on
Mouselet Abolishing business rates would not be a bad idea, but would increase council tax by about 50% which is a little hard to sell
Soundbuy I'd suggest we all shoplift at Amazon to make amends.............but there's a flaw....
BE11:14am

Though blending the massively profitable AWS and the loss leader retail bit together would make for some odd distortions.

Mouselet I'd have thought Amazon has a non-zero shrinkage rate due to people claiming falsely that packages never arrived. But it's a bit more obvious than sticking packets of dishwasher soap in your unusually large coat.
BE11:15am

Let's see if anyone's got any ideas on The Twitter .....

11:15 am
BE11:15am

BE11:15am

........... actually, let's not.

undefined
11:16 am
BE11:16am

Okay, so we're still in results season unfortunately

BE11:16am

Mondi mentioned earlier .....

Soundbuy Mondi would be nice............
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Morning folks.
Mondi PLC (MNDI:LSE): Last: 2,189, up 117 (+5.65%), High: 2,208, Low: 2,099, Volume: 1.15m
11:17 am
BE11:17am

Which did a very good H1. Operating profit up 25% thanks to the kraftliner and recycled box price hikes we've been talking about here since November.

BE11:18am

Plus, the exit rate looks good. No sign of a slowdown into H2.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Something has to be done about Amazon. Free-market nonsense leads to results that aren't always the best solution for a healthy society.
A. M. @Lt. Fletcher Christian: agreed, but what is that 'something'?
VV75 don't use them, it is that simple
BE11:18am

Goodbody incoming.

Mouselet What is wrong with Amazon? Why does a healthy society require umpteen wildly sub-scale poorly-located warehouses offering only in-person collection?
Mouselet If we had Amazon to begin with, nobody would have remotely suggested inventing the high street
11:19 am
BE11:19am

H1 beat and announce another round of containerboard price increases
Mondi has reported group underlying operating profit of €630m representing yoy growth of 25%. This compares to our forecasts of €583m, with the key variance being the packaging division. The other key point is the announcement that it is to increase European kraftliner prices by €40/tonne from September, the first such increase since February. Taken together this is a positive statement and at first glance we see forecasts increasing by 5% and as a result see the results being well received by investors.

Ethelred Once you strip out the AWS profit - does the rest of the business make much money? My understnding is that they will take over the world and then raise margins
#REF! Ultimately with amazon, its down to consumers. We see the reports on staff conditions and tax. But people use it anyway because convenient and cheap. At some point, consumers must take responsibility (myself included)
Mouselet Is being a shelf-stacker in Rymans really so good for the soul that it's worth losing the scale advantages in order to offer people that option?
BE11:20am

The Packaging Paper has reported strong performance with EBITDA growth of 43% to €430m, 15% ahead of our forecasts. This reflects strong pricing and as a result good cost recovery. Such momentum is set to continue with Mondi now the first out with another round of increases for kraftliner and a further 5-7% increase for kraft paper prices at the end of Q2 (follows 8-9% in January). Uncoated fine paper was the other division that was ahead of our expectations and as forecast EBITDA was under some pressure due to cost pressures. As a result, it is encouraging to see further price increases of 2-6% in July and a further 6% in September. The one area of slight disappointment is Consumer Packaging, which remains challenged and is impacted by one-off items around restructuring in the UK.

Ethelred In the interim stuff about transfer pricing and not paying much coporation tax is so much guff
BE11:20am

And UBS.

Mouselet ( I can see the argument that zero-visible-price delivery is a particularly strong exploitation of scale and has made life very crap for delivery drivers )
11:20 am
BE11:21am

What's next? High quality organic growth with opportunistic M&A
MNDI is making "good progress" with its key growth projects (Steti, Ruzomberok & Syktyvkar), which lift pulp & paper volumes 9% over next 3yrs and should deliver greater than 15% return; capex is still seen at €700-800m in 2018 & 2019. MNDI continues to streamline the portfolio in H1, selling a sack kraft mill in the US & starting a consultation process to close a consumer goods packaging plant in the UK. MNDI remains dynamic/opportunistic with M&A, acquiring an industrial bags plant in Egypt for €24m in Apr-18 & Powerflute (265kt SC-fluting) in Jun-18 for €363m. We expect MNDI to focus on deleveraging in 2018, with net debt rising €918m in H1 due to €484m special dividend & M&A €415m.

A. M. @Mouselet: possibly. The thing is that amazon and its ilk have replaced high-street jobs and business with a network of warehouses. Isn't it that the net effect is negative?
BE11:21am

Valuation: Buy; prices consolidating at elevated levels; high quality growth
We lift our tgt to £24/sh (from £23/s) based on 13x 2018E EV/EBIT. MNDI has rerated with packaging sector over the last 7yrs, driven by strong growth & improving returns; we see further upside with cycle robust & MNDI to deliver further high quality growth.

Plato the Cook Companies could pay a service charge instead of tax on profits, based on services received from the nation (infrastructure, security, ...?), a bit like council tax. Base it on numbers of employees, volume of goods, data, contracts
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @mouselet I guess we should all sit at home on our backsides, Ipad in hand, relying on the terrible gig economy to assist our sedentary lifestyle?
undefined
11:22 am
BE11:22am

(@Plato: I like that idea.)

casapinos Amazon will disappear when every home has a 3d printer to produce all the cr*p we need(?)
Mouselet Or sit in our air-conditioned offices working on either designing the next generation of thing, or on designing the category of thing that isn't in Amazon's purview
Mouselet 100% service economy is a goal
BE11:23am

(@AM: dunno. Give me a moment, I'll hit something with a spanner.)

Mouselet I think 'based on services received from the nation' is a recipe for companies to run their own inept police forces and roads
Shinshin AMZN - alternative min tax approach ? Pay higher $ value of 22% profit tax or 2% turnover tax. Have it only apply to >$100m t/o corps to reduce impact on SMEs.
Mouselet casapinos: I've used 3D printers, Amazon is in remarkably little danger
Mouselet shinshin: what is the point of mollycoddling SMEs?
Plato the Cook Taxing profits is as ubiquitous as taxing income, and both lead to artificial skewing of economic activity just to avoid tax
A. M. (@BE: thanks.)
casapinos mouselet :-)
#REF! Shinshin wouldn't that screw grocers on their 4% PBT margins, effective 50% tax rate?
Swedish Chef Belated Morning all. @mouse Walked through Plymouth high st earlier. BHS shuttered, House of Fraser on last legs maybe, lots of empty small units. The civic pride that rebuilt the place after the 1941 blitz absent. Kids skateboarding the Navy War memorial.
Shinshin @mouse because typically SMEs are not multinational transfer pricing double irish sandwich structures
Plato the Cook (Sigh) /ubiquitous/iniquitous/
#REF! I request Intertek grey, a FTSE 100 we rarely hear about (mainly because I don't want to try and understand RBS results)
EJ hello
DRichi I was told once that UK Tax laws have more words than the Bible. Taxation needs simplifying massively. Rip the whole thing up, start with a blank piece of paper and have a few different Income Tax rates, plus VAT. I could get the whole thing on 1 page. No ambiguities and therefore no tax dodging
Soundbuy Has he really gone looking for a spanner.....
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Who would blame him?
BE11:27am

Sorry --- that took a moment.

A. M. @Soundbuy: sometimes it requires just the threat, other times you really need to hit it. hard.
11:27 am
BE11:27am

On Amazon, spin back to the stuff we did on the day post the results.

Manxish @DRichi I believe they tried this in the early/mid 90s, didn't work
Soundbuy :)
Shinshin @ref eggs, omelettes...
BE11:28am

The theory seems to have moved from "they'll get an effective monopoly on retail etc and then push up prices to act like a normal company ......"

Swedish Chef @DRichi you could equally abolish all criminal law and replace with just two offences. “Being out of order” and being “bang out of order”.
A. M. @BE: where is the theory now (I dread to think)?
BE11:28am

To: "they'll maintain their effective monopoly on retail etc by staying unlike a normal company then use that scale to push the high margin stuff like AWS, advertising and subs."

Ethelred And then they will be regulated like a utility......
Manxish @DRichi Sorry, make that the late 90s
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @mouselet Sitting on your backside as a consumer isn't anywhere near as progressive as sitting on your backside designing something. Wealth has to be created and it doesn't get created by your nonsense of a 100% service economy because somebody has to serve. ;)
11:29 am
BE11:30am

And the right way to tax stuff AWS, advertising and subs. is ..... god knows. On where the server rack is based? Or where the end customer is? I've no clue.

BE11:30am

But back to more simple matters.

Pets at Home Group PLC (PETS:LSE): Last: 128.90, up 15.8 (+13.97%), High: 133.80, Low: 117.40, Volume: 1.97m
A. M. @Mouselet: regarding 3d printers, there are some rather gloomy possible outcomes in 'Four Futures' / 'Radical Technologies' -- namely, you may own the machine (though not the firmware), but you'll be asked to pay for the designs, etc.
11:30 am
BE11:30am

Big rally on four straight quarters of LFL growth

BE11:31am

There's not a lot else in today's trading update, beyond a reassurance on the full year

DRichi I think the internal tax bit could be done on a few pages of paper. Internally it's a bit more complex, would need a large addendum for all the WHT, and DTT between countries. And yeah- anyone avoiding tax should be charged with being "bang out of order!" haha!
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Maybe we should 3D print an FT journalist! :)
DRichi *Internationally not internally
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Only joking BE! :)
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Of course
Swedish Chef @first you can already print firearms. Useful for when the hoardes come for your Brexit stockpiles.
BE11:32am

(@Fletcher: I'd suggest that three dimensions is one too many.)

A. M. @Swedish Chef: is the raw material locally-made, or also in need of stockpiling?
11:33 am
BE11:33am

The only real surprise is "as part of our ongoing investment appraisal of new stores, we have decided not to proceed with the opening of two stores for which lease arrangements had been committed"

luzh Speaking of 3D printing, amazing paper yesterday: https://techcrunch.com/2018/07/26/this-3d-printed-ai-construct-analyzes-by-bending-light/
ActiveValue1 Why is PETS so heavily shored? Nothing obviously negative in the update this am.
FATDAZ @BE Was it pets at home that had issues with an in house vet business ?
ActiveValue1 "shorted"
luzh Light-speed light-powered DNN computing. Now *that* would trouble AWS margins
BE11:34am

Writing off £1.6m because you've decided that expansion isn't going to work ... that doesn't look great news to me .....

Mouselet yes, that is quite a fun paper. Doing DSP with special optical filters has been around for quite a while (I believe the first synthetic aperture radar did it); it is a very nifty technology if you don't mind vastly expensive set-up costs, and incredible faff aligning things with hierarchies of set-screws to be the right number of wavelengths of light from one another
BE11:34am

.... also note the new reporting structure, which shows it's the vets side that's driving LFL.

Mouselet Notice that you have to explicitly 3D-print the input image too, which is not confusable with convenience!
11:35 am
BE11:35am

13.6% vs 5.3% for retail.

Mr Gekko Any thing on TERN Plc ? AIM favourite, very odd RNS today
A. M. @Mouselet: just the training set, or also the actual input?
BE11:36am

Which, given the concerns that the vets business is structurally lossmaking due to the requirement to fund new practices with internal loans .... doesn't look that positive either?

Mouselet It seems quite ridiculous that there are no cooling-off arrangements, so you can't just pull out of the lease arrangement at a nominal fee which the landlord can use to hunt for the next customer
BE11:36am

But ....... it's cheap. Here's Liberum.

Mouselet AM: the actual input. The training's all done in software and the 3D-printed filters are a realisation of the optimised weight matrix
Mouselet Real applications of the custom-filtering use mirror arrays or LCD-on-silicon to form the input light
Mouselet but those are expensive and fiddly things to work with; do you spy a theme here?
11:37 am
BE11:37am

Having turned sellers on 5th July 2016,

Soundbuy fjp73 - he disappeared a tad after launching a mobile dog grooming service.............. bitten by the hand that fed him?
BE11:38am

the shares have fallen 53%.

BE11:38am

We move to HOLD today noting the 4th consecutive quarter of LFL sales greater than 5% and whilst FY forecasts remain unchanged, this raises questions around whether the earnings have troughed?

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Considering the PE of 8.6x, we feel the risk/reward profile may have shifted. We balance this more positive recommendation with continued areas of caution including 1) strong competitive pricing pressure 2) continued risks around gross margin, 3) a tough outlook in Vets and 4) a cash exhaustive vets model.

BE11:39am

Bit more there .....

Soundbuy I told him grooming a German Shepherd at 70mph was fraught with danger....
BE11:39am

Although visibility still remains relatively low, given the continued strength in trading performance we feel we may be closer to the trough than we have previously envisaged. While we remain conscious of the areas of caution, we move to HOLD noting the sub-10x PE valuation and what is clearly a surprisingly positive LFL sales performance in Retail. While the group has decided not to proceed with the opening of two stores, at cash cost of £1.6m, this is probably the right thing to do and we look favourably on Pets treating this as an underlying cost as opposed to an exceptional item.

A. M. (Mouselet: at some point someone would find a way of making it cheaper, I suppose that's the aim. Whether or not it's physically possible is another matter)
11:39 am
BE11:39am

And on vets .....

BE11:39am

This is a decent performance form the Vet Practice, and whilst the revenue growth is sequentially ahead from prior periods, one should not forget the £20m working capital outflow to support the vet practices and the shortage of vet practitioners in the marketplace alongside the concerning outlook provided by CVS yesterday

BE11:40am

I continue to argue, no longer as a lone voice it appears, that vets practices have structural reasons why they don't work well as listed companies.

luzh @Mouselet, yes the concept has been around for a long time, but thinking of the long-term it seems like huge potential, kind of in the same way that google's TPUs are starting to innovate in hardware to accommodate DNNs
11:41 am
undefined
GBKrona @BE - RBS?
hedgehog Tern looks a shocker
BE11:41am

RBS! Sure. Okay.

Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 257.90, up 7.8 (+3.12%), High: 259.80, Low: 255.10, Volume: 14.85m
11:42 am
BE11:42am

There's a divi!

Swedish Chef RBS+1
BE11:42am

Has anyone done the maths on how much that divi will go to the Treasury?

Mouselet Hardware to accelerate DNNs is one of those fiddly no-brainers, but at least it's hardware where the DNN coefficients are in memory (possibly some special weird memory having been processed by special weird compiler, but basically read/write memory)
BE11:43am

Perhaps we could all get a one-off tax cut funded by it. Though I guess it'd be in fractions of a pence.

11:43 am
BE11:44am

So ........ profit beats on lower impairments ...........

Mouselet It is interesting to see Google keeping it as an in-house option, Apple designing a block and using it as a reason to buy their phones, Qualcomm and Nvidia and Samsung designing a block and using it as a reason for phone-makers to buy their chips
BE11:44am

And settlement of RMBS means a 2p payout, which I think was consensus already.

Mouselet (and ARM now deciding that it's a block that they should have a version of in their enormous library of licensable hardware designs)
BE11:45am

Below the headline, it's a bit mixed. Ireland and Commercial Banking doing okay but NIM's edging lower and costs look a bit high.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

And a CET1 ratio of 16.1%

DRichi Gov owns 8.4 Billion shares at 2p div = £168,000,000 (I think I got the decimal point in the right place)
Playing FTSE @BE 62.4% gov owned = £150m to treasury of the £240m declared
BE11:46am

Management aiming to keep it above a 13% target, suggesting cash returns should be fairly generous.

BE11:47am

(Though not cash returns to the people who bailed RBS out, of course. Unless the Treasury wants to hold onto its stake, which it doesn't.)

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Here's Macquarie.

BE11:48am

There is undoubtedly significant excess capital in the group e.g. more than £4bn (or 33p per share) if the CET1 ratio was to be reduced to say 14%. Management targets taking the payout ratio up to 40% over time which means that based on longer term assumptions of around 30p of EPS, the implied longer term DPS of around 12p would represent a theoretical yield of close to 5%. Management also contemplated the use of other forms of capital distribution and we would expect buybacks in due course.

Mouselet Why do you buy a theoretical yield of close to 5% in the medium to longer term rather than, y'know, HSBC shares today?
BE11:50am

... thanks ROTR for the divi maths ......

GBKrona excellent point, Mouselet
11:50 am
BE11:50am

So, on a UK basis it's about £2 per person?

BE11:51am

The government could buy everyone a Coke and a packet of Haribo.

GBKrona @BE - but if taxpayers then probably £4 pp
BE11:51am

Good to know.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Here's RBC.

BE11:52am

Total income declined 12%yoy, a 2% beat versus consensus. Within this, NII decreased 3%yoy, 1% better than consensus, and non interest income
decreased 26%yoy, 4% better than consensus. The decline in income in H1 is primarily driven by a larger drag in the corporate centre due to IFRS volatility
movements. Loan growth is lower than we expect - UK PBB loans increased 2%yoy and commercial banking declined -8% - but NIM is better with mortgage
margin pressure offset by deposit margins.
Operating expenses decreased 2%yoy, 1% worse than consensus.
Impairments declined 10%yoy, 63% better than consensus.
Overall, PBT beat consensus by 11% (excluding restructuring costs and litigation and conduct).
Litigation costs of £782m are 37% better than consensus and include the previously announced civil settlement with the DOJ of £1.04bn offset by a £241m
provision release relating to RMBS litigation indemnity

sprout because dividend yields are a poor valuation metric?
BE11:52am

RWAs declined to £199bn from £203bn in Q1 ahead of consensus expectations £201bn). This faster than expected reduction and the lower litigation and
conduct lead to a CET1 ratio 60bps better than consensus at 16.1%, down from 16.4% in Q1. RBS continues to target a 13% CET1 ratio.
RBS announced its intention to pay a 2p dividend and increase the dividend payout ratio to 40% over time. RBS will consider further distribution in addition to
regular dividend pay-outs, subject to BOE stress test results.

11:52 am
BE11:53am

0.9x latest TBV and 8.9x 2019E P/E, they say. Which I guess goes some way to answering the HSBC question on the right.

FATDAZ RE RBS isn't the firm 'paying back' the UK taxpayer with their own money?
#REF! @ sprout indeed. Same logic 1 year ago "why by X when you can by Capita and Provident financial, lovely yields..."
BE11:55am

And Jefferies .........

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian "Why do you buy a theoretical yield of close to 5% in the medium to longer term rather than, y'know, HSBC shares today?" Because future realisation of yield tends to improve chances of capital appreciation rather than taking current yield.
BE11:55am

The price sensitive catalyst in this release is the intended interim DPS of 2p and guided regular pay-out ratio of 40% + further pay-outs in addition to the regular divvy. The regulator is clearly comfortable with this company repatriating capital and we would expect the return to be augmented post this year's stress test. On this note, capital generation was an area of positive surprise in Q2 (in a quarter that witnessed the pension top-up and DOJ settlement), with CET1 at 16.1% (post divvy accrual) v JEFe at 15.3%.

11:55 am
BE11:56am

The Q2 underlying PBT was 20% ahead of expectations, 10% ex one-offs. The variance was a non-interest income beat of 21% though this included non-recurring items of £120m, net of which non-interest income was 8% ahead. Net interest income was in-line at £2.18bn with a flat 281bps NIM QoQ in the UK PBB business (higher rates are driving better deposit margins, which are offsetting asset yield pressures – this is in line with our NIM thesis on RBS). The performance in the NatWest markets was disappointing (really the only negative element in today's release), with rates revenue -39% YoY, FX -30% YoY and Finance -14% YoY.
As elsewhere, impairments were much better, 63% better than expectations with a modest £63m charge in Q2.

BE11:56am

Hey, here's an idea. Rather than returning the surplus cash, why not head down the M&A route and turn RBS into an international champion?

BE11:57am

Perhaps buy something Dutch.

11:56 am
undefined
Soundbuy Ho ho........
GBKrona with RBS, Lloyds, BARC results recently it seems almost safe to dip a toe back into UK bank shares again??
BE11:57am

Speaking of, there's noise around in Pru again.

Prudential PLC (PRU:LSE): Last: 1,747, up 16.65 (+0.96%), High: 1,749, Low: 1,731, Volume: 1.39m
Soundbuy Try clogs next time -they'll keep them afloat.....
11:59 am
BE12:00pm

As Ben H noted the other day, one od the "interest in the UK division" rumours we hinted at ended up side panel in the Evening Standard .....

BE12:00pm

BE12:00pm

Yeah, Lloyds-M&G was indeed one of the suggestions.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Another is possible interest in the Asian side.

BE12:01pm

Though as we've said previously, Pru's going through a breakup process and it's natural that other parties will take an interest in that.

FATDAZ UBS has delta one piece out today suggesting that we may see a rotation out of tech and into financials i.e, out of growth and into value though where UK names will participate in that is another matter
BE12:02pm

Whether considerations and informal contact develop into anything is another question entirely.

12:02 pm
undefined
GBKrona Pru interims on 8th August should be very interesting - wnder if we will get more break-up detail then, and how much debt they can load into each of the two parts.
Blank canvas Thanks for everything this week. Time to hit the turps bottle again.
BE12:03pm

Through midday, but someone requested Intertek and we must show that we engage with you, the reader.

Soundbuy Bon w/end to left and right..........
Intertek Group PLC (ITRK:LSE): Last: 5,854, up 52 (+0.90%), High: 5,872, Low: 5,808, Volume: 120.30k
12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Buying Alchemy for $480m

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Yes. Thanks all. Have a good weekend BE & ROTR.
BE12:04pm

US thing. Looks sensible but a bit expensive, with a very long wait for the payback.

BE12:04pm

Alchemy does "People Assurance solutions to operations in the food industry" .... what this means in practice I'm not sure.

12:04 pm
BE12:05pm

Jefferies sort-of explains.

BE12:05pm

Their software solutions help clients drive safety, productivity, excellence and customer service by managing skills in front line staff and offering learning solutions on a 3-year subscription model. Intertek will roll these services out across all industries globally.

BE12:05pm

Nope, still don't get it. Jefferies not keen whichever way.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

At first take this deal looks to deviate from the strong M&A value creation
narrative.

Manxish Thanks BE, have a good weekend all
FATDAZ bye all have a good one
BE12:06pm

Intertek paid 7x EV/revenue and 22x EV/EBITDA on FY18 metrics. Subsequently, even factoring in 20% revenue growth per annum (organic growth was c.17% during 2016-18), EBITDA margins greater than 30% and EBIT margins greater than 25%, the deal does not cover cost of capital until year 5 (FY23). Under Andre Lacroix, M&A has been slow due to vigorous value creation requirements with deals needing to cover cost of capital in a downside scenario. We estimate mid-single digit EPS accretion in FY19.

#REF! thanks BE, I would have taken you saying "no to Intertek" as engagement also :)
BE12:07pm

JPM's keener.

12:07 pm
BE12:08pm

Maintaining standards of safety and quality is
becoming ever more critical in the food service industry. The
reputational and financial consequences of getting it wrong mean food
companies take effective compliance very seriously and this, in our
opinion, is only likely to intensify. Alchemy provides what Intertek
describes as the ‘leading platform' for safety and compliance training
with a breadth of proprietary content that makes it, while still arguably
sub-scale with billings of $66 million in FY18E, a differentiated asset.

BE12:08pm

The 2018E acquisition multiple is 21.8x adjusted billings EBITDA, but the
business delivers a high ROCE and is expected to grow at c20% pa,
meaning we expect the purchase multiple to decline rapidly in the out
years (to 18x in FY19E and 15x in FY20E), and the return on Intertek's
investment to exceed its cost of capital within 5 years. Our EPS estimates
rise by 1% in FY19 and FY20.

undefined
GBKrona Great session in a hot week - thanks BE / ROTR. Stay cool.
12:10 pm
BE12:10pm

Have we missed anything? Probably. I'll chuck the odds and ends here: https://www.ft.com/stocks-to-watch .......

BE12:10pm

.................. In the meantime, thanks for sticking around both today and this week.
